facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1175 and 1178 of 1970 were filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 11751178 of 1970.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and order dated December 9, 1964 of Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 146 of 1963 and Writ Petitions Nos. 698 to 700 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and order dated December 9, 1964, of the Madras High Court in Tax Case No. 146 of 1963 and Writ Petitions Nos. 698 to 700 of 1963.

facts.text: The assessee is a limited company carrying on business of tea planting.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee, who is the respondent is a limited companypany carrying on business of tea planting.

facts.text: Assessee owns several tea estates in Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Assam.

anchor.surface_text: It owns several tea estates in the States of Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Assam.

facts.text: Head office of assessee is in Munnar, Kerala.

anchor.surface_text: Its head office is in Munnar in the State of Kerala.

facts.text: Chittavurai Tea Estate owned by assessee comprises 1043 acres of tea plantations.

anchor.surface_text: One of the tea estates owned by the assessee is called Chittavurai Tea Estate and companyprises 1043 -acres of tea plantations.

facts.text: 1006.60 acres of Chittavurai Estate situate in Kerala, 36.40 acres in Tamil Nadu.

anchor.surface_text: Out of this an area of 1006.60 acres is situate in Kerala and the remaining 36.40 acres, in Tamil Nadu.

facts.text: According to assessee, Chittavurai Estate works as one unit.

anchor.surface_text: According to the assessee Chittavurai Estate is working as one unit.

facts.text: One factory manufactures tea grown in Madras and Kerala portions of Chittavurai Estate.

anchor.surface_text: There is only one factory manufacturing tea grown in the Madras and Kerala portion of the estate.

facts.text: Expenses incurred for maintenance of whole Chittavurai Estate as one unit.

anchor.surface_text: The expenses are incurred for the maintenance of the whole estate as one unit and companymon accounts are maintained for it,

facts.text: Common accounts maintained for Chittavurai Estate, no separate account for Madras portion.

anchor.surface_text: companynon accounts are maintained for it, there being numberseparate account for the Madras portion.

facts.text: Central Income tax Officer computed loss for entire Chittavurai Estate treating as one unit.

anchor.surface_text: As pointed out by the High Court the companyputation by the Central, Income tax Officer showed a loss for the entire Chittavurai Estate.

facts.text: Agricultural Income tax Officer computed profit for Madras portion of Chittavurai Estate.

anchor.surface_text: the Agricultural Income tax Officer took the valuation of the produce from the Madras portion as the gross receipt. He deducted from it the.expenditure allowed by the Central Income tax Officer and recalculated it from the Madras portion on the basis of acreage. That led to a profit from the Madras portion.

facts.text: Apportionment of expenditure treating whole estate as one unit resulted in loss for Madras portion and profit for Kerala portion according to AITO.

anchor.surface_text: According to him apportionment of expenditure by treating the whole of Chittavurai Estate as one unit had resulted in a loss for the Madras portion and a profit for the Kerala portion.

facts.text: Tea from Chittavurai Estate grown in Madras but manufactured in Kerala.

anchor.surface_text: It can have numberapplicability in the present case where even though tea is grown inside that State but it is manufactured in Kerala which is outside that State.,

facts.text: Madras portion of Chittavurai Estate is more fertile and gives more yield than Kerala portion.

anchor.surface_text: It is only a very small area of that estate which is in Madras even though that is more fertile and gives much more yield. than the area in Kerala

facts.text: High Court held that Rule 7 applicable only to tea grown and manufactured in Madras.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly pointed out that R. 7 is applicable only to agricultural income from tea grown and manufactured in the State of Madras.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: High Court declined to give finding on whether CITO computation legally binding in all cases on AITO.

anchor.surface_text: That companyrt, therefore, declined to give a finding on thequestion whether the Central Income tax Officers companyputation should be held to be legally binding in all cases and in all circumstances on the Agricultural Income tax Officer.

facts.text: Agricultural Income tax Officer did not give sufficient reasons for not accepting Central Income tax Officer's computation.

anchor.surface_text: the High Court which went into the facts and figures of the various assessments came to the companyclusion that the. Agricultural Income tax Officer had number given sufficient reasons for number accepting the Central Income tax Officers companyputation.
Section 2 1  of the Indian Income tax Act 1922 hereinafter called the Income tax Act defines agricultural income. The 119Sup. Cl/72 1019 per acre.

s. 6 of the Agricultural Income tax Act and Rules 7 and 8 framed under that Act. Section 6 provides that where agricultural income is derived from land situated partly within the State and partly without the State agricultural income tax shall be levied- Where the portion of such income attributable, to the land situated within the State can be determined from the accounts maintained by the assessee, on the portion so determined Where the portion of the income so attributable cannot be determined by the method specified in clause  i , on such portion as may be determined in the prescribed manne r.

concepts.interpretation: Applies where agricultural income derived from land partly within and partly without the State; portion attributable determined from accounts or prescribed manner (Rules).

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: the agricultural income from tea grown and manufactured in the State of Madras or refuse to accept the companyputation of the Indian Income tax Office

concepts.unlisted_description: Levy of tax on agricultural income from land situated partly within and partly without the State

anchor.surface_text: Rules 7and 8 are as follows- R.7 Computation of income from tea.-In respect of agricultural income from tea grown and manufactured by the seller in the State of Madras, the portion of the income worked out under the Indian Income tax Act and left unassessed as being agricultural shall be assessed under the Act after allowing such deductions under the Act and-the rules made thereunder Provided that the computation made by the Indian Income tax Officer shall ordinarily be accepted by the Agricultural Income tax Officer who may, for his satisfaction under sections 16 and 16 of the Act, obtain further details from the assessee or from the Indian Income tax Officer but shall not without the previous sanction of the Assistant Commissioner of Agricultural.

concepts.interpretation: Applicable only to agricultural income from tea grown and manufactured in the State of Madras; not applicable where tea grown in Madras but manufactured in Kerala; computation by ITO ordinarily to be accepted by AITO unless sufficient reasons.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: for ,computation of income from tea. Therefore, R. 8 can have numberapplicability particularly when the language employed in it cannot companyer the c

concepts.unlisted_description: Computation of income from tea grown and manufactured in Madras; ordinarily accept ITO computation

anchor.surface_text: R.8 Computation of income derived from lands situated partly within the State and partly without.-Where an agricultural. income is derived from lands situated partly within the State and partly without the State and the-income attributable to the lands situated within the State cannot be determined by the assessee but where the value of the produce grown within or without the State can be separately determined from the accounts maintained by the assessee such income shall be computed in proportion to the value of the respective quantity of produce raised within or without the State. In other cases such income shall be computed in proportion to the respective cultivated acreage of the crop lying within and without the State if the crop grown is the same, subject to such modifica- tions as may be necessary with reference to the yield per acre, the quality of the produce and the price fetched within and without the State.

concepts.interpretation: Moot whether applicable to tea; not applicable as tea leaves alone not valuable produce, value after manufacturing; Rule 7 specific for tea; language does not cover tea.

anchor.surface_text: Anglo-American Direct Tea Trading Co. Ltd. etc. etc. v. Commissioner of Agricultural Income tax Kerala 1 . In that case it was held that agricultural income taxable under the Kerala Agricultural Income tax Act 1950 was 60 of the income computed under the Income tax Act after deducting therefrom the allowances authorised by s. 5 of the Kerala Act insofar as the same had not been allowed in the assessment under the Income tax Act.

concepts.interpretation: AITO bound to accept computation of tea income made under Income-tax Act if made prior; allow additional deductions under AIT Act.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: s 60 of the income companyputed under the Income tax Act after deducting therefrom the allowances authorised by s. 5 of the Kerala Act insofar as the

issues.text: Whether Rule 7 is applicable only to agricultural income from tea grown and manufactured in the State of Madras and has no applicability where tea is grown in Madras but manufactured in Kerala

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly pointed out that R. 7 is applicable only to agricultural income from tea grown and manufactured in the State of Madras. It can have no applicability in the present case where even though tea is grown inside that State but it is manufactured in Kerala which is outside that State., As regards R. 8 it is a moot point whether the same would be applicable to tea.

issues.text: Whether Rule 8 is applicable to tea

anchor.surface_text: As regards R. 8 it is a moot point whether the same would be applicable to tea. So far as tea is concerned the tea leaves alone can be the produce but as such they have no value. They become valuable only after they are subjected to a special process from which emerge various brands of tea. Rule 7 has specifically been framed for ,computation of income from tea.

issues.text: Whether Rules 7 and 8 can be of any avail or assistance to the Agricultural Income tax Officer in the present case

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to see how these two rules can be of any avail or assistance to the Agricultural Income tax Officer in the present case. It must be remembered that Chittavurai Estate being of tea falls in a special class.

issues.text: Whether the Agricultural Income tax Officer had given sufficient reasons for not accepting the Central Income tax Officer's computation
Whether the Central Income tax Officer's computation should be held to be legally binding in all cases and in all circumstances on the Agricultural Income tax Officer

Whether in every case the Agricultural Income tax Officer is bound to accept the computation made by the Central Income tax authorities and only allow additional deduction which may be permissible under the Agricultural Income tax Act

arguments.claim: In Anglo-American case, AITO bound to accept prior CITO computation of tea income under Kerala Act

anchor.surface_text: Our attention has been invited on behalf of the assessee to a decision of this Court in Anglo-American Direct Tea Trading Co. Ltd. etc. etc. v. Commissioner of Agricultural Income tax Kerala. In that case it was held that agricultural income taxable under the Kerala Agricultural Income tax Act 1950 was 60% of the income computed under the Income tax Act

arguments.court_reasoning: Principle on same lines as present case

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ention to s. 6 of the Agricultural Income tax Act and Rules 7 and 8 framed under that Act. Section 6 provides that where agricultural income is derive

arguments.court_reasoning: CITO showed overall loss; insufficient reasons to deviate

holdings.text: R. 7 is applicable only to agricultural income from tea grown and manufactured in the State of Madras and has no applicability in the present case where tea is grown inside that State but it is manufactured in Kerala which is outside that State.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court rightly pointed out that R. 7 is applicable only to agricultural income from tea grown and manufactured in the State of Madras. It can have no applicability in the present case where even though tea is grown inside that State but it is manufactured in Kerala which is outside that State.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court correctly interpreted plain language of Rule 7 requiring both growing and manufacturing within Madras.

holdings.text: R. 8 has no applicability to tea as tea leaves alone are not valuable produce until subjected to manufacturing process and Rule 7 is specifically framed for computation of income from tea.

anchor.surface_text: As regards R. 8 it is a moot point whether the same would be applicable to tea. So far as tea is concerned the tea leaves alone can be the produce but as such they have no value. They become valuable only after they are subjected to a special process from which emerge various brands of tea. Rule 7 has specifically been framed for computation of income from tea.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Language of Rule 8 refers to value of produce which tea leaves lack pre-manufacturing; Rule 7 is specific provision for tea.

holdings.text: Rules 7 and 8 can be of no avail or assistance to the Agricultural Income tax Officer in the present case as Chittavurai Estate being of tea falls in a special class.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, R. 8 can have no applicability particularly when the language employed in it cannot cover the case of tea. We are unable to see how these two rules can be of any avail or assistance to the Agricultural Income tax Officer in the present case. It must be remembered that Chittavurai Estate being of tea falls in a special class.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Tea estates like Chittavurai form special class not covered by general rules 7 and 8 due to integrated operations across states.

holdings.text: The rule that the Agricultural Income tax Officer should accept the computation of the Central Income tax Officer furnishes the only satisfactory basis for computation of agricultural income tax in respect of Chittavurai Estate and the unit has to be assessed as a whole.

anchor.surface_text: It is only a very small area of that estate which is in Madras even though that is more fertile and gives much more yield than the area in Kerala but the unit has to be assessed as a whole and the High Court, in our opinion, rightly thought that the rule that the Agricultural Income tax Officer should accept the computation of the Central Income tax Officer furnishes the only satisfactory basis for computation of agricultural income tax in respect of Chittavurai Estate.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Estate operates as single unit with common factory, expenses, accounts; CITO computation shows overall loss; proviso to Rule 7 supports ordinarily accepting CITO computation; analogous to Kerala precedent.

holdings.text: The Agricultural Income tax Officer had not given sufficient reasons for not accepting the Central Income tax Officer's computation.

anchor.surface_text: Moreover the High Court which went into the facts and figures of the various assessments came to the conclusion that the Agricultural Income tax Officer had not given sufficient reasons for not accepting the Central Income tax Officers computation. That court, therefore, declined to give a finding on the question whether the Central Income tax Officers computation should be held to be legally binding in all cases and in all circumstances on the Agricultural Income tax Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court reviewed facts and figures of assessments and found lack of sufficient reasons; Supreme Court endorses.

precedents.cited_holding: agricultural income taxable under the Kerala Agricultural Income tax Act 1950 was 60% of the income computed under the Income tax Act after deducting allowances under s.5 of Kerala Act not allowed under Income-tax Act; AIT Officer bound to accept computation by Central authorities if assessment made prior

anchor.surface_text: Moreover the High Court which went into the facts and figures of the various assessments came to the conclusion that the Agricultural Income tax Officer had not given sufficient reasons for not accepting the Central Income tax Officers computation. That court, therefore, declined to give a finding on the question whether the Central Income tax Officers computation should be held to be legally binding in all cases and in all circumstances on the Agricultural Income tax Officer.
The appeals fail and are dismissed with companyts. Hearing fee, one set.
